young.label: Young Adult
young.context: At your age, building healthy habits now creates a strong foundation for lifelong wellness. Your body is resilient but not immune to the effects of poor lifestyle choices.

adult.label: Adult
adult.context: In your 30s and early 40s, metabolism begins to slow and stress levels often peak. Preventive action now has outsized long-term benefits.

midlife.label: Mid-life Adult
midlife.context: At this stage, cardiovascular health, bone density, and metabolic function deserve close attention. Small consistent changes yield significant results.

senior.label: Senior
senior.context: Maintaining mobility, strength, and cognitive health are key priorities. Focus on low-impact activity, nutrition quality, and regular health screenings.

underweight.label: Underweight
underweight.summary: Your BMI indicates you are underweight, which carries its own health risks including nutrient deficiencies, weakened immunity, and reduced bone density.
recommendations: Increase your caloric intake with nutrient-dense whole foods like nuts, legumes, and whole grains
Incorporate strength training at least 3 times per week to build lean muscle mass
Consult a nutritionist to ensure you are meeting your daily macro and micronutrient needs
Avoid skipping meals and consider adding healthy calorie-dense snacks between meals
preventiveActions: Track your daily caloric intake for 2 weeks to understand your eating patterns
Get bloodwork done to check for deficiencies in iron, vitamin D, and B12
Monitor your energy levels and mood as these are early indicators of nutritional gaps

normal.label: Normal Weight
normal.summary: Your BMI is in the healthy range, which is a strong indicator of good metabolic health. The focus now is maintaining this through consistent habits.
recommendations: Maintain your current weight through a balanced diet rich in vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains
Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic activity per week
Schedule annual health checkups to monitor cholesterol, blood pressure, and blood sugar
preventiveActions: Keep a consistent sleep schedule of 7-8 hours to support metabolic health
Monitor your weight monthly rather than daily to track meaningful trends
Stay up to date with recommended health screenings for your age group

overweight.label: Overweight
overweight.summary: Your BMI places you in the overweight category, which increases risk for cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and joint stress. The good news is this range is very responsive to lifestyle changes.
recommendations: Aim for a modest caloric deficit of 300-500 calories per day through diet adjustments rather than extreme restriction
Increase physical activity to at least 45 minutes of moderate exercise 5 days per week
Reduce ultra-processed foods, sugary drinks, and high-sodium snacks from your daily diet
Focus on portion control rather than elimination — small reductions compound significantly over time
preventiveActions: Get your blood pressure and blood sugar checked every 6 months
Start meal prepping to reduce reliance on fast or convenience food
Consider working with a registered dietitian to build a sustainable eating plan

obese.label: Obese
obese.summary: Your BMI is in the obese range, which significantly elevates risk for serious conditions including heart disease, stroke, sleep apnea, and type 2 diabetes. Proactive steps now can dramatically reduce these risks.
recommendations: Consult your doctor before starting any new exercise program to ensure it is appropriate for your current condition
Begin with low-impact activities such as walking, swimming, or cycling to protect your joints
Work toward reducing added sugar and refined carbohydrates as a first dietary priority
Set small, measurable weekly goals rather than focusing on large long-term targets
preventiveActions: Schedule a full health panel including HbA1c, lipid profile, and liver function tests
Consider joining a structured weight management program with professional support
Track your daily steps as a starting metric and aim to increase by 500 steps per week

Low.description: Your overall health risk score is low. Continue your current healthy behaviors and focus on prevention.
Low.urgency: Maintain current habits with annual monitoring.

Moderate.description: Your health risk score indicates moderate risk. Targeted lifestyle improvements can significantly reduce this.
Moderate.urgency: Take action within the next 30 days and reassess in 3 months.

High.description: Your health risk score is elevated. This warrants prompt attention and ideally professional guidance.
High.urgency: Seek medical advice within 2 weeks and begin lifestyle changes immediately.

poor.summary: Your posture score is critically low, which can lead to chronic back pain, reduced lung capacity, and long-term spinal issues.
tips: Set an hourly reminder to check and correct your posture throughout the day
Strengthen your core with daily exercises like planks, dead bugs, and bird dogs
Invest in an ergonomic chair or standing desk if you sit for long periods
Consider seeing a physiotherapist for a posture assessment and corrective exercise plan

average.summary: Your posture score is average. You have a foundation to build on but noticeable room for improvement.
tips: Focus on shoulder blade retraction exercises to counteract forward head posture
Stretch your hip flexors and chest daily as these tighten with prolonged sitting
Be mindful of your screen height — your monitor should be at eye level

good.summary: Your posture score is good. Maintaining this requires consistent effort especially as activity levels or work habits change.
tips: Continue your current posture habits and incorporate mobility work into your routine
Reassess your ergonomic setup every 6 months especially if your work setup changes

Low.summary: Your hydration is low. Chronic dehydration affects kidney function, cognitive performance, skin health, and energy levels.
tips: Start each morning with a large glass of water before coffee or food
Carry a 1-liter water bottle and aim to refill it twice daily
Eat water-rich foods like cucumber, watermelon, and leafy greens
Set phone reminders every 2 hours to drink water until it becomes habit

Moderate.summary: Your hydration is at a moderate level. A small increase would noticeably improve your energy and focus.
tips: Add one extra glass of water with each meal to boost your daily intake
Replace one sugary or caffeinated drink per day with water or herbal tea

High.summary: Your hydration is good. Well done — consistent hydration supports nearly every system in your body.
tips: Adjust your water intake upward on days with intense exercise or high heat
Include electrolyte-rich foods post-workout to maintain optimal balance

Sedentary.summary: A sedentary lifestyle is one of the strongest independent risk factors for cardiovascular disease, metabolic disorders, and mental health decline.
tips: Start with a 10-minute walk after each meal — this alone has measurable metabolic benefits
Break up sitting time every 45 minutes with 5 minutes of light movement
Set a daily step goal of 5,000 steps initially and increase by 1,000 each week
Find a physical activity you genuinely enjoy — consistency matters more than intensity

Lightly Active.summary: You have some activity in your routine but there is meaningful room to increase it for better health outcomes.
tips: Add one structured workout session per week targeting either cardio or strength
Try replacing short car trips with walking or cycling where possible
Use the stairs instead of elevators as a simple daily habit upgrade

Moderately Active.summary: You are moderately active which puts you ahead of most people. Optimizing your routine can take your results further.
tips: Introduce interval training once a week to boost cardiovascular efficiency
Add resistance training if you are not already doing it — muscle mass improves metabolism
Focus on recovery — stretching, sleep, and nutrition are limiting factors at this level

Very Active.summary: Your activity level is excellent. At this level the focus shifts to sustainability, recovery, and injury prevention.
tips: Ensure you are consuming enough calories and protein to support your activity level
Prioritize sleep as the primary recovery tool — aim for 8-9 hours
Include at least one full rest day per week to prevent overtraining syndrome

combinedRiskFlags.sedentaryHighRisk: You are both highly sedentary and in a high risk category — this combination significantly accelerates health deterioration. Physical activity is your single highest-impact intervention right now.
combinedRiskFlags.youngHighRisk: Being in a high risk category at a young age is unusual and worth taking seriously. Early intervention now prevents compounding health issues in your 30s and 40s.
combinedRiskFlags.seniorModerateRisk: At your age, moderate risk requires prompt attention. Cardiovascular and metabolic conditions progress faster after 60 — regular medical monitoring is essential.
combinedRiskFlags.lowHydrationHighRisk: Chronic dehydration combined with high health risk amplifies strain on your kidneys and cardiovascular system. Improving hydration is one of the fastest changes you can make today.
combinedRiskFlags.poorPostureHighRisk: Poor posture combined with high health risk compounds physical stress on your body. Addressing posture reduces chronic pain and fatigue that otherwise makes other healthy habits harder to maintain.
